I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During  the  2005  Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) confirmed its request for technical assistance (TA) from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to prepare the Energy Conservation and Resource Management 
Project.1 In July 2005, the Fact-Finding Mission was fielded to assess the results of available 
studies and determine the scope of the TA. The Mission held discussions with representatives 
from the Government and concerned provincial government officials. An understanding was 
reached  on  the  TA  goals,  purpose,  scope,  cost  estimates,  financing  and  implementation 
arrangements,  and  the  consultants’  terms  of  reference.  The TA is included in the country 
pipeline for 2005. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The increased use of energy to fuel the economic growth of the PRC economy has 
contributed significantly to increased environmental pollution: in the power sector, because of its 
heavy  dependence  on  coal-fired  power  generation  and  limited  investment  in  appropriate 
environmental  abatement  technology;  and  in  the  industry  sector,  because  of  obsolete 
production processes and reliance on coal. The PRC has abundant coal resources, which are 
relatively inexpensive to produce. In 2004 about 1.9 billion tons of coal was produced, of which 
about 50% was used for power generation. According to official data, emissions of major air 
pollutants peaked in 1995 and subsequently declined. This decline was mainly the result of 
industry sector restructuring, closure of state-owned enterprises, trade liberalization, energy 
efficiency, and the use of cleaner production technologies. Because energy efficiency has 
improved, emissions of carbon dioxide (CO ) are less than were projected in the early 1990s. In 
2
recent years, however, air pollution has been picking up again and is a serious problem, 
considering that more than 63% of the major cities do not meet the Grade II national air quality 
standards. 
 
3.  The demand for energy in the PRC will continue to increase in the future, with projected 
economic growth rates of around 8% per annum; a low level of per capita energy consumption, 
which  is  about  one  tenth  of  that  of  the  United  States  (for  instance,  current  electricity 
consumption by households is only about 4% of electricity consumption by households in the 
United States); an emerging high rate of motorization in the transport sector; and a rapid 
urbanization process to accommodate a minimum of 10 to 12 million rural emigrants a year. 
 
4.  PRC’s  energy  sector  will  continue  to  be  characterized  by  a  high  level  of  coal 
consumption that meets about 63% of its primary commercial energy demand, a large number 
of persons involved in coal production and transportation, and an extensive coal infrastructure. 
A significant and rapid shift away from coal in the medium term is unlikely due to the limited oil 
and gas reserves and potential for further development of its hydropower resources. Using the 
most optimistic scenario of increased use of domestically produced natural gas, importation of 
liquefied natural gas (LNG), and timely construction of the required natural gas distribution 
networks, it is expected that the share of natural gas in the primary commercial energy mix 
could reach only 10% by 2020. 
 
5.   With the economy expected to maintain rapid growth over the coming years, a steep 
decline in pollution intensity (pollution caused per unit of gross domestic product (GDP) will be 
necessary if emissions are to be kept at current levels. Industrial pollution intensities, pollution 
loads, and contamination of the ambient environment will most certainly increase unless the 
Government’s  pollution  abatement  incentives  are  adjusted.  At  present,  environmental  and 
health costs associated with the use of coal are not internalized; in other words, there is no level 
playing field for other more environment-friendly fuels, such as natural gas and renewable 
energy vis-à-vis coal. Increasing the minimum height of smokestacks for coal-fired plants, and 
                                                 
1 The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 15 April 2005.

2 
introducing market-based instruments (such as taxation of coal use and use of sulfur dioxide 
[SO ] emission trading permits) would contribute to leveling the field. 
2
 
6.  Pollution caused by the use of coal is aggravated by the relatively high energy intensity 
of PRC’s economy, which requires about 3.8 times more energy per unit of economic output 
than the world average. The situation is mainly due to (i) ongoing development of energy 
efficiency standards and inadequate enforcement of existing ones, (ii) inefficient energy price 
signals  for  consumers,  (iii)  low  investments  in  energy-efficient  technologies  and  practices, 
(iv) relatively large contribution of energy-intensive production of fixed assets to GDP, (v) lack of 
a legal and regulatory framework to adopt effective demand-side management (DSM) policies, 
and (vi) need for capacity building in energy conservation at local and national levels.  
 
7.  The Government has recognized that the potential for energy conservation in the PRC is 
enormous and will provide considerable benefits in terms of reduced use of energy resources, 
reduced financing requirements for new energy supply projects, increased security of energy 
supply,  and  reduced  emissions  associated  with  increasing  energy  consumption.  The 
Government has therefore set as a broad target to quadruple GDP between 2000 and 2020, but 
only  to  double  energy  consumption  during  this  period.  In  January  2005,  the  National 
Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) published the China Medium- and Long-Term 
Energy  Conservation  Plan.  The  plan  aims  to  give  priority  to  energy  conservation  over 
development of new sources of energy to fuel PRC’s economic growth, and targets an average 
annual reduction of 2.2% in energy intensity from 2003 to 2010. Energy conservation is to be 
achieved in all major industries and specific key projects have been identified in industries such 
as retrofit projects, energy system optimization projects, construction of cogeneration power 
plants and energy-efficient buildings, DSM projects, and capacity building for promoting and 
implementing energy conservation projects.  
 
8.  The PRC has already been very successful in achieving energy savings in industrial 
boilers and energy-intensive industries such as steel, cement, and chemicals that contributed to 
a 70% decrease in energy consumption per unit of economic output between 1980 and 1998. 
Those industries have also been targeted under the China Medium- and Long-Term Energy 
Conservation Plan for further energy savings through the installation of more energy-efficient 
boilers, equipment, and production processes following the introduction and implementation of 
corresponding  stricter  energy  efficiency  standards.  As  recognized  in  the  plan,  there  is 
considerable potential for energy conservation through DSM programs. In this context, DSM 
refers to a set of tools and practices to decrease the cost of meeting consumers’ demand for 
electricity through investments that enable better management of the electricity load on the grid 
and more efficient use of electricity by the end users. In particular, DSM programs aim to reduce 
the peak demand for electricity—which requires power generation capacity that is used only 
when the daily peak occurs—through load management and by promoting the use of more 
energy-efficient equipment and appliances by electricity consumers. 
 
9.  DSM programs are not yet being implemented in the PRC on a large scale, but studies 
done so far have found that (i) the potential for cost-effective DSM is very large, (ii) the cost of 
meeting PRC’s demand for additional power through investments in both DSM and new power 
generation  capacity  is  less  than  the  cost  of  meeting  such  demand  through  new  power 
generation capacity and new power transmission and distribution systems only, (iii) DSM is fully 
consistent with PRC’s goal for sustainable development of its energy sector, (iv) DSM is a 
proven and effective method for immediately addressing anticipated power shortages in the 
PRC, and (v) successful implementation of DSM in the PRC will require the adoption of policies 
and rules that support DSM and make it an integral part of power sector reform and power 
sector planning.2  
 
                                                 
2 For instance, it is estimated that enforcement of improved energy efficiency standards and introduction of incentives 
for DSM would make the construction of new power generation capacity of 100 gigawatts up to 2020 unnecessary.

3 
10.  ADB has financed an initial study of the DSM potential in Jiangsu province. It was found 
that  an  investment  of  $220  million  for  installing  and  using  high-efficiency  commercial 
cooling/lighting equipment, industrial motor drive systems, and residential appliances, which is 
also referred to as “the efficiency power plant (EPP) project concept” will obviate the installation 
of new power generation capacity of 600 megawatts. In general, it is estimated that such energy 
conservation projects would make additional electricity available at 25% less than its present 
cost.  However,  to  move  such  an  EPP  project  concept  forward,  an  appropriate  policy  and 
regulatory  framework  has  to  be  developed.  The  framework  should  provide  incentives  for 
electricity suppliers and consumers to install energy-efficient equipment and appliances, fairly 
distribute  costs  and  benefits  between  electricity  suppliers  and  consumers,  establish  a 
mechanism for (partial) financing of energy-efficient equipment and appliances and collecting 
payments from beneficiaries, and set implementation and verification rules for EPP projects. 
 
11.  Findings of studies carried out so far indicate that it is crucial for successful initiation and 
implementation of an EPP project to overcome market barriers. In this regard the preferred 
option is for local power transmission and distribution companies to provide the energy-efficient 
equipment and appliances to the various consumers, with a subsidy as compensation for the 
higher cost of the more energy-efficient equipment and appliances and the surrender of the 
equipment and appliances in use, and subsequently recover this subsidy cost from an additional 
charge in the electricity tariff for energy conservation.3 Alternatively, energy services companies 
(ESCOs) could provide energy-efficient equipment for relatively large electricity consumers and 
recover their investment for a service charge levied on them. Based on studies already done 
and  detailed  available  information  about  the  economic  benefits  and  financial  costs  of 
implementing EPP projects in the PRC, an EPP demonstration project can be developed only if 
at the same time national policy and regulatory issues are addressed to ensure that appropriate 
incentives for all parties to undertake such an EPP project will be provided, including a fair 
distribution of its obvious economic benefits among the national and provincial governments, 
investors, suppliers of electricity, and beneficiaries. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The objective of the TA is to assist NDRC identify various options and corresponding 
requirements for the development of an appropriate policy and regulatory framework to promote 
and  implement  EPP  projects.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  the  establishment  of  such  a 
framework. The TA will also prepare the general design for a demonstration EPP project in a 
specific province in the PRC, including an estimate of its economic and financial cost and 
benefits, and recommend implementation and financing arrangements for such a project.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  Adoption of the TA recommendations will promote EPP projects and the prefeasibility 
study will allow the development of an EPP demonstration project. Also, staff of concerned 
agencies will be trained in conducting energy conservation surveys that will provide the required 
technical information for preparing other EPP projects. The TA will comprise two parts. In part A 
(options for establishing a policy and regulatory framework for EPP projects), consultants will 
assist the Power Division of the Economic Operations Bureau (PDEOB) of NDRC with identifying 
various  options  and  corresponding  requirements  for  developing  an  appropriate  policy  and 
regulatory framework to promote the implementation of EPP projects. In part B (prefeasibility 
study for an EPP demonstration project), consultants will assist a particular Provincial Economic 
and Trade Commission (PETC) in preparing a prefeasibility study for the development of an EPP 
demonstration project. Part B will be in two phases. During phase 1, the consultants will review 
available data, gather additional data through a survey, and, in consultation with NDRC, identify a 
                                                 
3  Such a charge for energy conservation in the electricity tariff has been adopted in many countries, but is not used 
in the People’s Republic of China.

4 
province where an EPP demonstration project is to be developed and the economic benefits of an 
EPP demonstration project would be the highest.  During phase 2, the consultants will prepare a 
prefeasibility  study  for  developing  an  EPP  demonstration  project  in  the  selected  province, 
identify the required assistance for capacity building and institutional strengthening programs at 
the  provincial  level  to  ensure  successful  implementation  of  the  EPP  project,  and  identify 
possible funding sources for such assistance. During TA implementation, two workshops will be 
held to simultaneously discuss the findings and recommendations of the consultants for parts A 
and B. The first workshop will be held at the completion of phase 1 of part B of the TA and will 
discuss  the  initial  findings  of  the  consultants  with  regard  to  options  and  corresponding 
requirements for developing an appropriate policy and regulatory framework to promote the 
implementation of EPP projects as well as views with regard to the preferred province for which a 
prefeasibility study for an EPP demonstration project is to be prepared. The second workshop will 
be held at the end of the TA to discuss the findings and recommendations of the consultants 
with regard to the development of an appropriate policy and regulatory framework for EPP 
projects and the prefeasibility study for an EPP demonstration project in a province as agreed 
upon with NDRC. The workshops will be organized by the consultants recruited for part A and 
will  be  attended  by  organizations  and  parties  interested  in  the  EPP  concept:  government 
organizations and concerned policy makers at the national and provincial levels and other 
relevant government agencies in the province where the EPP demonstration project is to be 
developed,  and  aid  agencies.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  the  consultants  are  in 
Appendix 2. 
 
14.   Key activities in part A will include (i) reviewing the Government policies, practices, and 
targets to promote energy conservation; (ii) evaluating the EPP concept and its implementation 
in other countries; (iii) reviewing the present electricity tariff structure and annual government 
review and adjustment procedures; (iv) assessing the economic benefits of using the EPP 
concept in selected areas in the PRC where the potential for energy conservation by small 
electricity users is high; (v) identifying possible government policies and regulations that would 
be needed to provide adequate incentives for adopting the EPP concept in those areas; and 
(vi) prioritizing options for such a policy and regulatory framework and actions to be taken by the 
Government for its development. 
 
15.  Key activities in part B, will include (i) reviewing available data and surveys in connection 
with the development of an EPP demonstration project; (ii) selecting a particular province for the 
EPP demonstration project; (iii) assessing areas where further critical survey is to be conducted, 
and  training  staff  in  conducting  additional  surveys;  (iv) identifying  priority  areas  within  the 
selected province where the development of an EPP demonstration project would provide the 
highest economic and financial benefits to the PRC and the concerned province; (v) assessing 
the  general  scope  and  components  of  such  an  EPP  demonstration  project,  and  its  cost, 
financing requirements, and economic and financial viability and sustainability; (vi) assessing 
the social and environmental benefits of an EPP demonstration project; (vii) identifying required 
implementation  arrangements;  and  (viii)  assessing  the  required  capacity  building  and 
institutional strengthening. 
 
16.  The  major  risks  in  the  successful  implementation  of  the  TA  include  inadequate 
counterpart support, inadequate data and its untimely provision, delayed submission of required 
studies, delayed consultant selection, and poor consultant performance. In addition, support by 
national and concerned provincial governments and their participation in the workshops are 
necessary. Efforts will be made to ensure timely recruitment of competent international and 
domestic consultants. Close coordination among the consultants, executing and implementing 
agencies, and ADB will mitigate the risks. It is understood that implementation of the TA does 
not commit any party to provide further financial or other assistance required for developing an 
EPP demonstration project.

5 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $850,000  equivalent  (Appendix  3).  ADB  will  provide 
$600,000 equivalent on a grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program. NDRC will contribute 
$250,000 equivalent, representing about 33% of the total TA cost. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  PDEOB will be the Executing Agency for parts A and B, while the concerned PETC will 
act as Implementing Agency for part B. ADB will select and engage the services of international 
and domestic consultants according to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. Consultants for 
part A, will have expertise in developing of policies and regulatory frameworks to promote 
energy conservation, energy economics, electricity pricing and tariff development, and DSM 
activities,  including  application  of  the  EPP  concept.  An  estimated  21  person-months  of 
consulting services will be required for part A—3 international and 18 domestic. Consultants for 
part B, will have expertise in developing and monitoring DSM projects, financial and economic 
analyses, social and environmental aspects of energy conservation, and capacity building and 
institutional  strengthening  for  energy  conservation.  An  estimated  27  person-months  of 
consulting services 7 international and 20 of domestic will be required. The international and 
domestic consultants for parts A and B will be provided by a firm that will be selected separately 
for each part following the submission of simplified technical proposals and the use of the 
quality- and cost-based selection method. The TA is expected to begin in early March 2006 and 
be completed by December 2006. 
 
19.  PDEOB will assign two counterpart staff to work with the consultants on a daily basis. 
For part B, NDRC will cause the concerned PETC to establish a provincial steering committee 
comprising  representatives  from  the  Provincial  Development  and  Reform  Commission,  the 
Provincial Finance Bureau, and the Provincial Pricing Bureau to review and discuss policy, 
regulatory, and economic aspects of the proposed EPP demonstration project, in consultation 
with PDEOB. For this purpose, the latter will organize regular meetings with the provincial steering 
committee during TA implementation. NDRC will also cause the concerned PETC to establish a 
working group comprising representatives from PETC, the provincial power transmission and 
distribution company, DSM Center, regional electricity distribution companies, and concerned 
municipal governments to work closely with the consultants; and to assign two staff of the 
working group to work with the consultants daily. The working group will report directly to the 
provincial steering committee on the progress of part B of the TA, and the committee will advise 
PDEOB of the same. PDEOB and the concerned PETC will jointly organize the two workshops 
for the TA, which will be held in Beijing. PDEOB will provide interpreters, local transportation, 
and office space with suitable facilities in Beijing, while NDRC will cause the concerned PETC to 
provide the same for the consultants during their work in the concerned provincial capital. 
Computers  and  other  office  equipment  financed  under  the  TA  will  be  procured  by  the 
international economist in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement and transferred to 
PDEOB after completion of the TA. 
 
        IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Energy Conservation and Resource 
Management, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 2 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 
 
A.  Options for Establishing a Policy and Regulatory Framework for Efficiency Power 
Plant (EPP) Projects (Part A) 
 
  1.   Background   
 
1.  In part A of the technical assistance (TA), the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will select 
and engage the services of international and domestic consultants according to its Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants. The main objective of part A is to identify various options and 
corresponding  requirements  for  the  development  of  an  appropriate  policy  and  regulatory 
framework to promote and enable the implementation of efficiency power plant (EPP) projects in 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC). The consultants will work closely with the Power Division 
of  the  Economic  Operations  Bureau  (PDEOB)  of  the  National  Development  and  Reform 
Commission (NDRC)—the Executing Agency for part A—and ensure effective transfer of know-
how. When the TA starts, the consultants will do a detailed background study to thoroughly 
understand issues in developing EPPs in the PRC. The consultants will review reports and 
studies of NDRC, government agencies, and international agencies, including ADB, Energy 
Foundation, European Union, World Bank, United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), 
and  other  aid  agencies.  The  consultants  will  provide  the  overseas  experience  in  EPP 
implementation  and  present  recommendations  for  implementing  EPP  in  the  PRC.  The 
consultants will evaluate international experience in related areas and its relevance to the PRC, 
and tailor their recommendations to ensure these are relevant to and can be implemented in the 
PRC. Part A will be implemented over about 9 months beginning in early March 2006. 
 
  2.  Terms of Reference 
 
2.  Experts for part A should have knowledge and experience in power pricing, electricity 
marketing, power demand-side management (DSM), and electricity conservation. An estimated 
21 person-months of consulting services will be required: 3 international and 18 domestic. The 
international consultants will include a power pricing expert, team leader, a DSM expert, and a 
power  marketing  expert.  The  domestic  consultants  will  include  a  power  pricing  expert,  a 
financial analyst, a DSM expert, and an energy conservation expert. The consultants for part A 
will coordinate closely with the consulting team in part B preparing a prefeasibility study for an 
EPP demonstration project in a particular province. The consultants’ tasks will include but will 
not be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Review the Government’s policies, practices, and targets to promote energy 
conservation.  
(ii)  Assess the barriers to implementing EPP options in the PRC’s current electricity 
regulatory framework. 
(iii)  If  the  EPP  concept  is  considered  generally  viable,  identify  options  and 
recommend a set of policies at the national level that would be necessary in 
developing and implementing EPP projects. 
(iv)  Evaluate the EPP concept and implementation arrangements in other countries. 
(v)  Review  present  electricity  tariff  structure  and  adjustment  procedures  and 
economic  assessment  of  the  appropriateness  of  present  electricity  tariffs, 
including time-of-use pricing. 
(vi)  Assess of the economic benefits of using the EPP concept in selected areas in 
the PRC where the potential for energy conservation by small electricity users is 
high. 
(vii)  Identifying possible government policies and regulations that will be required to 
provide adequate incentives for adopting the EPP concept in such areas.

(viii)  Recommend procedures and options for implementing EPP in the PRC and 
evaluate resources needed and the potential for implementing it. 
(ix)  Propose the required government action to promote implementation of EPP, 
region by region, and at different levels. 
(x)  Introduce  the  key  models  for  adopting  EPP  based  on  those  currently 
implemented in other countries. 
(xi)  Analyze the procedures and financing scheme for each model. 
(xii)  Evaluate all models and identify their advantages and disadvantages. 
(xiii)  Prepare  policy  reforms  and  guidelines  to  allow  tariff  surcharges  required  for 
implementing  an  EPP  project,  and  options  for  implementing  the  scheme, 
including  approaches  where  both  economic  and  financial  objectives  are 
simultaneously achieved.  
(xiv)  Prepare a policy scheme for including the EPP costs in the cost of electricity 
production to implement EPP. 
(xv)  Assess other options for EPP financing and their policy implications. 
(xvi)  Study and design a suitable cash flow model for an EPP project and analyze the 
flowchart for implementing an EPP project. 
(xvii)  Prioritize options for a policy and regulatory framework and actions to be taken 
by the Government for EPP development. 
(xviii)  In consultation with NDRC and the consultants engaged for part B, organize two 
workshops in Beijing. 
(xix)  In  consultation  with  ADB,  prepare  an  overseas  study  tour  for  concerned 
government officials.  
(xx)  Prepare general guidelines for appraisal and postevaluation of EPP projects. 
 
  3.  Reporting Requirements 
 
3.  The consultants will submit the following reports: 
 
(i)  An  inception  report  within  1  month  after  the  start  of  part  A.  The  report  will 
summarize the initial findings and suggest changes, if any in the TA's approach, 
methodology, and time schedule.  
(ii)  A midterm report to NDRC and ADB. The two will have 3 weeks to review the 
report before the first workshop. ADB staff will participate in the workshop. The 
consultants will assist NDRC with organizing the workshop. The workshop’s main 
objectives are to (a) present to policy makers, concerned government parties, 
and aid agencies the initial TA findings and recommendations; (b) facilitate idea 
exchange  and  gather  comments;  (c)  increase  the  sense  of  ownership  and 
commitment to the TA recommendations; and (d) allow policy makers to discuss 
feedback received. 
(iii)  A final report, taking into account the (a) comments of NDRC and ADB on the 
draft final report, to be submitted within 2 months after the first workshop; and 
(b) discussions during the second workshop. The consultants will assist NDRC 
with organizing the second and final workshop with policy makers, concerned 
government  parties,  and  aid  agencies  to  discuss  the  TA  findings  and 
recommendations. NDRC and ADB will have 3 weeks to review the draft final 
report prior to the workshop. Following the workshop, the consultants will prepare 
the final report and translate it into Chinese.

10  Appendix 2 
 
B.  Prefeasibility Study for Establishing an EPP Demonstration Project in a Particular 
Province (Part B) 
 
  1.  Background 
 
4.  For part B, ADB will select and engage the services of international and domestic 
consultants according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The main objective of 
part B is to prepare the general design for a demonstration EPP project in a particular province 
in  the  PRC,  including  estimates  of  its  economic  and  financial  cost  and  benefits,  and 
implementation  and  financing  arrangements  recommended  for  such  a  project.  To  ensure 
effective  transfer  of  know-how,  the  consultants  will  work  closely  with  the  working  group 
established by the Implementing Agency for part B; the concerned Provincial Economic and 
Trade  Commission,  comprising  representatives  from  the  concerned  provincial  power 
transmission and distribution company; the national DSM Center; regional electricity distribution 
companies; and concerned municipal governments. Part B will be carried out in two phases. 
Phase 1 will review available data, gather additional data through a survey, and consult with 
NDRC  in  identifying  a  particular  province  for  an  EPP  demonstration  project  and  where  the 
economic benefits would be highest. In phase 2 the consultants will prepare a prefeasibility study 
for an EPP demonstration project in the selected province. They will review existing reports and 
studies on energy conservation in the PRC prepared by government agencies and by aid 
agencies, including the ADB, Energy Foundation, European Union, World Bank, and UNDP. 
The consultants will coordinate their recommendations on the policy and regulatory aspects of 
an EPP demonstration project with the overall recommendations for implementing a policy and 
regulatory framework for EPP projects in the PRC to be made by the consultants for part A of 
the TA. Part B will be implemented over about 9 months beginning in early March 2006. 
 
2.  Terms of Reference 
 
5.  Experts for part B should have knowledge and experience in developing and monitoring 
DSM projects, financial and economic analyses, social and environmental aspects of energy 
conservation, and capacity building and institutional strengthening for energy conservation. An 
estimated  27  person-months  of  consulting  services  will  be  required:  7  person-months 
international and 20 person-months domestic. The international consultants will include an EPP 
design  and  implementation  expert  team  leader,  an  economic  analyst,  a  financial 
analyst/financial management specialist, a social/environment specialist, and a capacity building 
expert.  The  domestic  consultants  will  include  a  DSM  expert,  an  energy  economist,  a 
heating/cooling engineer, a lighting engineer, an industrial engineer, a professional accountant, 
and  an  EPP  marketing/business  development  specialist.  The  consultants  for  part  B  will 
coordinate closely with the consultant team for the part A. Part B of the TA will be implemented 
in two phases. 
 
6.  Data Analysis and Collection (phase 1). The consultants’ tasks will include but will not 
be limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Review the basic data, relevant information, statistics, and technical reports on 
the  potential  for  energy  conservation  in  the  PRC  and,  in  particular,  for  the 
implementation of an EPP project. 
(ii)  Review  the  available  software  for  designing  EPP  projects  and  determine  its 
economic and financial costs and benefits. 
(iii)  Upgrade the available software and hardware and develop a computer program 
for  designing  an  EPP  demonstration  project  and  analyze  its  economic  and 
financial costs and benefits.

Appendix 2  11 
 
(iv)  On a preliminary basis, determine in order of priority three provinces/municipal 
areas  in  the  PRC  where  development  of  an  EPP  demonstration  project  will 
generate the highest economic benefits. 
(v)  Determine the general economic, industrial, and social structure of those areas 
and determine what additional data and information are required for determining 
the optimum location of an EPP demonstration project.  
(vi)  Design and carry out a targeted survey for this purpose and take the additional 
information into account in selecting the priority area, and consult with NDRC 
with regard to the findings. 
(vii)  In consultation with the consultants for part A, help organize the first workshop at 
the end of phase 1 to discuss the initial findings of the consultants for parts A and 
B,  including  findings  and  recommendations  on  the  priority  area  for  an  EPP 
demonstration project. 
 
7.  Prefeasibility Study (phase 2). The consultants’ tasks will include but will not be limited 
to the following: 
 
(i)  Determine the general design and scope of the EPP demonstration project that is 
expected  to  generate  the  highest  economic  returns,  including  its  major 
components and their cost estimates and compare its characteristics and salient 
features with those of current EPP projects abroad. 
(ii)  Estimate the implementation period and financing requirements for the project 
and identify possible sources and arrangements for such financing. 
(iii)  Determine  the  direct  beneficiaries  from  the  project,  including  the  concerned 
provincial electric power transmission and distribution company and electricity 
consumers, and estimate the long-term financial benefits for each. 
(iv)  Propose  institutional  and  organizational  arrangements  for  implementing  the 
project, for example, replacement and/or installation and use of energy-efficient 
equipment and appliances under the project and monitoring/certification of their 
use,  use  of  energy  service  companies  (ESCOs),  technical  departments  of 
provincial companies and organizations, suppliers of equipment and appliances,  
rebate schemes, etc. 
(v)  Identify key market barriers that justify government support for the development 
and implementation of the project.  
(vi)  Carry out financial and economic analyses of the project in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines for Financial Analysis of Projects, Guidelines for Economic 
Analysis of Projects, as well as Guidelines on the Financial Governance and 
Management of Investment Projects Financed by ADB; in particular, determine 
whether the project constitutes the least-cost expansion of power generation in 
the concerned province. 
(vii)  In consultation with the consultants under part A, identify the required general 
policies and regulations that would need to be adopted to allow cost recovery of 
the investments made for the project and a fair distribution of its costs and 
benefits over all parties involved. 
(viii)  Determine  the  expected  environmental  benefits  of  the  project,  including  its 
contribution to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, estimate the potential value of 
certified emission reductions (CERs) that could be generated and sold under the 
project, and identify further action required to enable such sales in the future. 
(ix)  Incorporate into the economic analysis a quantification of environmental benefits 
as a result of the project in accordance with ADB’s Environmental Guidelines for 
Selected  Industrial  and  Power  Development  Projects,  Environmental 
Assessment  Requirements  and  Environmental  Review  Procedures,  and 
Economic Valuation of Environmental Impacts: A Workbook, 1996.

12  Appendix 2 
 
(x)  Prepare  a  summary  initial  environmental  examination  of  the  project  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  prescribed  format  in  Environmental  Assessment 
Requirements and Environmental Review Procedures.  
(xi)  Estimate  the  number  of  poor  people  who  will  benefit  from  the  project,  and 
prepare a social analysis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Incorporation 
of Social Dimensions in ADB Operations. 
(xii)  Identify  requirements  for  institutional  strengthening,  capacity  building,  and 
training  to  ensure  successful  implementation  of  the  project,  and  evaluate 
possible sources for financial support for such activities. 
(xiii)  Prepare a general outline of a public awareness campaign, extension services, 
and other EPP-related promotional activities to complement the project. 
(xiv)  Assess the potential for replicating the project in the PRC. 
(xv)  Develop a general monitoring and evaluation system for the project comprising a 
set of monitoring indicators for economic growth, energy efficiency, institutional 
reforms,  poverty  and  social  aspects,  and  environmental  improvement.  The 
indicators should be appropriate for the monitoring system’s objectives, the main 
stakeholders, the speed with which the information must be supplied, and the 
cost. 
(xvi)  In  consultation  with  the  consultants  for  part  A,  help  organize  the  second 
workshop at the end of phase 2 to discuss the findings of the consultants for 
parts A and B, including the prefeasibility study for the project. 
 
3.  Reporting Requirements 
 
8.  The consultants will submit the following reports: 
 
(i)  An inception report within 1 month after the start of part B.  The report will 
summarize the initial findings and suggest changes, if any, in the TA's approach, 
methodology, and time schedule.  
(ii)  A report for phase 1 to NDRC, the concerned PETC, and ADB.  The three will 
have 3 weeks to review the report before the first workshop. ADB staff will 
participate  in  the  workshop.  The  consultants  will  assist  NDRC  and  the 
consultants  for  part  A  with  organizing  the  workshop.  The  workshop’s  main 
objectives are to (a) present to policy makers, concerned government parties, 
and aid agencies the initial TA findings and recommendations; (b) facilitate idea 
exchange  and  gather  comments;  (c)  increase  the  sense  of  ownership  and 
commitment to the TA recommendations; and (d) allow policy makers to discuss 
feedback received. 
(iii)  A final report, taking into account the (a) comments of NDRC, the concerned 
PETC, and ADB on the draft final report to be submitted within 2 months after the 
first workshop; and (b) discussions during the second workshop. The consultants 
will assist NDRC and the consultants for part A with organizing the second and 
final workshop with the participation of policy makers, concerned government 
parties,  and  aid  agencies  to  discuss  the  TA  findings  and  recommendations. 
NDRC and ADB will have 3 weeks to review the draft final report before the 
workshop. After the workshop, the consultants will prepare the final report and 
translate it into Chinese.
